description: Borrowed from French embarrasser (‚Äúto block, obstruct‚Äù), from Spanish embarazar, from Portuguese embara√ßar, from em- (‚Äúin‚Äù) (from Latin im-) + bara√ßo (‚Äúnoose, rope‚Äù), the latter ultimately being from Akkadian íÑô (GUR /markasu/, ‚Äúrope‚Äù).

verbs.description: embarrass (third-person singular simple present embarrasses, present participle embarrassing, simple past and past participle embarrassed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) to humiliate; to disrupt somebody's composure or comfort with acting publicly or freely; to abash.
examples: The crowd's laughter and jeers embarrassed him.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To hinder from liberty of movement; to impede; to obstruct.
examples: The motion was advanced in order to embarrass the progress of the bill.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To involve in difficulties concerning money matters; to encumber with debt; to beset with urgent claims or demands.
examples: A man or his business is embarrassed when he cannot meet his pecuniary engagements.

entries.meaning: (transitive, dated) To perplex mentally; confuse, disconcert; catch off guard.
